title: Preview of Metabolism
objectives: Understand biochemical forms of energy and ATP generation
Recognize redox potential and electron flow in metabolism
Describe major metabolic strategies and phases

overview.title: Pathway Overview
overview.content:
Definition & Classification

Metabolism is defined as the sum of all chemical changes in living cells, tissues, and body that results in:

  • Production of energy
  • Synthesis of small and large biomolecules
  • Growth and development
  • Elimination of waste material

Classification:

  • Anabolic pathways: Formation of macromolecules from simple precursors
  • Catabolic pathways: Breakdown of macromolecules into simple molecules (H2O, CO2, NH4+) to produce energy
  • Amphibolic pathways: Crossroads between anabolic and catabolic pathways (e.g., citric acid cycle)

biochemical_energy.title: Biochemical Energy
biochemical_energy.content:
Energy Carriers

  1. ATP (Universal energy currency)
    • Formed from ADP + Pi via oxidative phosphorylation (mitochondria) or substrate-level phosphorylation
    • Phosphocreatine system shuttles energy from mitochondria to cytosol
    • Adenylate kinase produces ATP from 2ADP (ATP + AMP)
  2. Other nucleotides (GTP, UTP, CTP)
    • GTP yields GDP + Pi to activate substrates
    • UTP/CTP form UDP/CDP-substrate intermediates
  3. Coenzyme A (CoA)
    • Carries acyl/acetyl groups
    • Essential for fatty acid metabolism
  4. Reducing equivalents (NAD, NADP, FAD, FMN)
    • Electron carriers for redox reactions

regulation.title: Regulation
regulation.content:
Metabolic Strategies

  1. Activation of Molecules
    • Phosphorylation/pyrophosphorylation
    • Adenylation
    • CoA binding
  2. Enzymatic Catalysis
    • Enables rapid, isothermic reactions
    • Example: Decarboxylation occurs at body temperature (vs 200°C in vitro)
  3. Coupled & Sequential Reactions
    • Energy-releasing reactions drive energy-consuming ones
  4. Targeted Bond Instability
  5. Specialized Carrier Molecules

clinical.title: Clinical Notes
clinical.content:
Clinical Correlations

  • Phosphocreatine Deficiency: Impacts muscle energy metabolism (skeletal/cardiac)
  • CoA Deficiency: Disrupts fatty acid metabolism (from pantothenate deficiency)
  • Electron Transport Disorders: Mitochondrial diseases affecting ATP production
  • Enzyme Deficiencies: e.g., Pyruvate kinase deficiency causes hemolytic anemia

faqs.title: FAQs
faqs.content:
Frequently Asked Questions

Q: Why is ATP called the 'universal energy currency'?

A: Because it's the common intermediate that links energy-producing and energy-consuming processes in all cells, with standardized energy value (~7.3 kcal/mol per phosphate bond).

Q: How does phosphocreatine help muscles?

A: It acts as an energy reservoir - quickly regenerates ATP during bursts of activity and shuttles mitochondrial ATP to cytosolic sites of use.

Q: Why are enzymes crucial for metabolism?

A: They enable life-compatible reaction speeds at body temperature (e.g., decarboxylation at 37°C vs 200°C required without enzymes).

Q: What's the clinical significance of redox potential?

A: It predicts electron flow direction in metabolic pathways. Disruptions (e.g., in ETC) cause diseases like mitochondrial disorders.
